review_blob: This is the 06 version. The first of a cellared six pack. The aroma is really hot, almost bourbon like. Very surprising to me with 5 yrs on this bottle. Light carbonation with a thin vinous mouthfeel. Earthy malty flavor that deepens as it warms. Overall, a bit of a disappointment.

A very forgettable pale ale. Nothing particularly bad but all together unremarkable. It always amazes me with breweries like this that can make such an amazing IPA and then drop the ball so thoroughly with the pale ale.

Good seasonal that I enjoy every year. BBC does very similar things on most of their beers and this one I think exemplifies the best of what they do. Big malt backbone with light hopping in the British tradition. If you are looking for a big ABV hop bomb you will be disappointed. Check your expectations and you will find a well crafted beer that strangely enough stands out for its lack of extremist tendencies and doesnt follow the big beer crowd. If your worried that it doesnt pack enough punch for the cold winter months, well its only sold in 22 oz bombers so that should make up the difference. Quantity and quality.

Great velvety, almost milky, med/full mouthfeel on this one with a sharpness at the end. The flavor and aroma were a bit muted with the choco coffeeness. Overall, kind of a ordinary drinker with the palate a standout feature.

Resinous aroma of apple and a hint of apricot. A salty smooth mouthfeel with a bit of malty citrus. Far too bitter even for the style. Sharpness on the palate and lingering well after. Love the brewery and like this series but wasnt crazy for this one.

Chocolate coffee and roast. An IPAs bitterness coupled with slippery malt. The chocolate malt melds brilliantly with the bittering hop.This is outstanding. I wouldnt expect anything less from the best brewery in New England. Robust indeed.

Bottle seems to be over carbonated as it poured a ridiculously massive head into my Duvel glass. Nonetheless, the aroma is outstanding. Yeasty with a fruit and honey center. The flavor is a smooth malt with a slight bitterness on the end. Like most belgian beer its all about the yeast. I can taste no trace of alcohol which makes this superbly drinkable. Ahh, if only all beer was this well crafted....life would make much more sense.

Good citrus and floral aroma even detected a hint of bubblegum? The flavor is a bit less potent and complex than the aroma but that isnt particularly unusual. Astringent bitterness on the end. Nice mouthfeel and good body without being too heavy. No trace of alcohol. This definitely rises above the normal Harpoon offering and actually stands up very well against the Founders Double Trouble I just had. I definitely wasnt expecting this.

A surprisingly good and flavorful impy. The choco-coffee notes were all there with enough give to let the roasted malt still come through. It doesnt have as big a body a some others but this makes it eminently drinkable. I found no trace of alcohol. Decent complexity with the chocolate, coffee and roast all mingling nicely. A pleasantly superb offering from a brewery that I felt was otherwise mediocre.
beer_name: Long Trail Brewmaster Series Coffee Stout

review_blob: This was a nice surprise. The aroma of Belgian yeast. Delicious. A billowy white head and a golden body. A mellow apricot and melon flavor with crisp hop and carbonation.  Slick mouthfeel with a medium body. Eminently drinkable. Damn I love this style. Good job North Coast.

The original is usually the best and in this case it just might be. It never disappoints. It has all the hallmarks of a great beer: flavor, balance and drinkability. Im not a huge fan of fuggles but it surely works in this classic. Pour me another.

This was drinkable but utterly blank. It had a slight everything. A slight aroma of hop and a slight taste that never became more than bland. Not offensive in any way but just a waste of time. It seemed to me the brewer sleep walked through this one.

I cant call this a IIPA it just doesnt fit and would doom this beer to complete failure anyway. The label says a "big pale ale" which is closer to the truth but relative to other "big" beers doesnt fit either. Nevertheless, I really had to dig for the aroma. A malty and slightly citrus mellowness. The flavor is malty almost dirty with a mild hop bitterness. This brewery has always struck me as one that never wanted to step too far out on a limb flavorwise and this beer falls in lock step with that philosophy. It does enough to be recognized as craft beer but never does anything particularly distinct. The body and mouthfeel are the only facet of this brew that can carry the tag of a bigger beer. It is a medium to full body with a creamy quite luscious mouthfeel. 
It is definitely east coast with no signs of the hop aggression  of a prototypical west coast IPA/APA, which depending on your tastes may or may not be appealing. Overall, this is more of a "big" sessionable pale ale that is pleasing but not particularly memorable.

Really nothing much happening in the aroma. A bit of earthy malt and lager. The flavor is malty with a bit of fruitiness and little to no hop. It does have a nice light-medium body with a smooth and quite pleasant mouthfeel. Highly drinkable and definitely meant to be a session choice.

The cadillac of IPAs. This beer defines what "balance" is in a beer. A lush citrus hop balanced by smooth malty sweetness. The aroma is magnificent with a forest full of fruit to savor. The mouthfeel lends itself to a session despite the 7.25%. A pleasure to drink from beginning to end. Im still waiting for regular distribution out here in the East. Damn.

Malty sweet with a lot of chocolate and roast in the flavor and aroma. The mouthfeel is incredibly creamy and velvety. Much more body than I anticipated. No trace of alcohol. A pleasure to drink. One of their best.

12oz bottle: A dry hoppy nose with a bit of sweet malt. The flavor is dry with a nice malt balance to quench the palate. A good medium body with soft carbonation. A very good version of the style. Tasty.

12oz bottle: Pours a muddy brown with a nice crusty head that dissipates. Aroma is a pleasant mix between piney hops and biscuit malt. The flavor is much of the same but with a nice spicy underbelly. The body is medium and slightly creamy with a soft mouthfeel. This is delicious. Ive found my new Autumn session brew.

12oz bottle: Aroma of citrus and malt sweetness. The first thing that struck me was the full and rich body on this beer. This has the thickness of a double IPA. A smooth creamy and slick mouth feel with mild carbonation. The flavor is typical for the style but has a slight lingering bitterness that was a bit distracting. Overall, this was a solid and surprising IPA especially the deep malt profile that gave a nice thirst quenching quality.

750ml bottle: Hops up front in the aroma with a yeasty malty background. Tasted initially dry and crisp but as it warmed the fruitiness of the dense malt backbone gave a nice balance and finish. A dense golden color with a good clean white head. Good creamy bready mouth feel. Nice and fruity on the finish. Good summer offering from Cisco.

12oz bottle: A cloudy brown pour with a slight head that dissipates. A lush aroma of sweet malt, cream, coconut, bourbon and slight alcohol. The flavor is mellow sweetness with the bourbon aging blending and melding very nicely. Its not obtrusive at all. In fact, it gives a nice complimentary sweet and creamy coconut like flavor. A slick creamy mouth feel and full body make this very drinkable despite the 9.3 ABV. This is an excellent beer. I think I"ll grab another.

12oz bottle: Great earthy aroma with coriander and undertones of citrus and peaches. A light yellow pour with a clean white head. The flavor was a bit short with just a hint of what the aroma offered. Light bodied and a lightly carbonated mouth feel. A little dull on the tongue. Refreshing and drinkable but not particularly memorable.

22oz bottle: Minimal aroma of tea leaves and sweet malt. A fairly weak flavor with really only the malt and the spice from the Juniper berries coming through. Light bodied with mild carbonation. Somewhat interesting because of the Juniper but otherwise quite disappointing and bland.

12oz bottle: A red brown pour with a small dissipating head. Initial hoppines in the nose but it then recedes to a malty slickness. A nice crisp mouthfeel with decent balance between hop bitterness and caramel maltiness. Light bodied. Seems like a good session brew. Nice and dry on the finish. A good six pack beer.

11.2oz bottle: A dark ruby pour with a decent head. Aroma of dark fruits like plums and raisins with a pronounced alcohol vapor. Flavor is rich malty sweetness with the plums and raisins melding nicely. Even though this is malty it is by no means too sweet. It is very smooth with only a little of the alcohol coming through despite the aroma. A great full body with a nice tingly mouth feel. An excellent beer with great drinkability. Better as it warms.

22oz bottle: A clear gold pour with a nice bleach white head that lingers. Aroma of yeast, gum, a bit of banana and coriander. The tastes matches the aroma and has a medium body that is creamy on the palate. Great lacing all the way down the glass. Clean finish. A nice Saison and one of the better American versions of the style.
beer_name: Smuttynose Big Beer Series: Farmhouse Ale

review_blob: 22oz bottle:A syrupy black pour with a good dirty brown head. Coffee, roast and alcohol in the nose. Sweet and syrupy on the tongue with an incredibly full body. The flavor is much less alcohol than the aroma. It is better as it warms with a nice dark richness and a slight bitterness that balances and rounds out the syrupy sweetness. I would like to see how one of these tastes after about six months in the cellar.

22oz bottle: Pours a dark brown with a rusty brown head. Aroma of cascade hops and choc. malt. Flavor is excellent dark chocolate and cocoa with a slight hop bitterness. A nice full body and slick syrupy mouth feel. This is definitely a sweet stout to be reckon with. It has rich chocolate notes but is not too sweet. A nice dryness on the end makes you thirsty for more. Very good.

12oz bottle: Pours an orange brown. Aroma is slightly hoppy but mostly malt sweetness. Decent body with a crisp hop bite that is overpowered by the malt especially towards the end. Smooth mouth feel. This was good but nothing special. A bit overrated.

12oz bottle: Initial floral hoppy aroma with the sweetness of the malt taking over. An orange copper pour with a minor head. Good medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor starts out with hop bitterness but quickly progresses to a malt sweetness. Mouth feel is slick and smooth. Solid IPA.

12oz bottle: A red copper pour. Aroma is sweet malt with floral and pine hops. Good flavor with caramel maltiness and a striking bitterness. This is definitely bottle conditioned as there was an impressive amount of sediment that scattered throughout the beer. This might turn some people off but I like it. There was also an interesting spiciness underneath the hop bitterness. My initial impression was that it was somewhat unbalanced but as it warmed the malt backbone really took over and made for a more mellow experience. Overall, an interesting beer that I will enjoy having again.

22oz bottle (100 barrel series): Good banana aroma with some bubble gum and clove. Flavor is more of the same. Tastes more like a Hefe than a saison. It lacks the dry crispness of the style. But still tasty nonetheless. Medium to light body and slightly creamy mouth feel. A good beer if not quite what Im looking for in a saison.

22oz bottle: Floral hops and rich wet malt in the nose. This would have been pretty ordinary if not for the nice crisp hop balance. The flavor strikes a nice harmony between the grainy sweet malt and the subdued hop bitterness. The body is medium and the mouth feel is mellow and smooth.  Great drinkability. Im glad I still have another in the fridge.

12oz bottle: A nice aroma hops coffee and roast. Taste much the same with good balance between the coffee bitterness and the malty sweetness. No alcohol presence on the palate. A medium to full body with a smooth silky mouth feel. This is very tasty. Certainly the best Flying Dog has to offer. Ill definitely pick this up again.

22oz bottle: Hoppy floral aroma with slight sweet malt. Flavor is citrus and malt with a raking bitterness. The body is medium and thinner than I expected. This is a little unbalanced with the malt not quite catching up with the hop bitterness. Bitter aftertaste lingers. Alcohol on the finish. This was decent but could have been better. I was definitely expecting more.
beer_name: Rogue XS Imperial India Pale Ale (IPA)

review_blob: 750 ml bottle: Aroma of mellow yeast and mild banana with a slight sourness. Great looking cloudy golden pour with crisp white head. The flavors are the citrus/coriander and a nice mellowing honey that creates a great creamy texture on the palate. This is totally full bodied and so smooth on the tongue. A slight crispness on the end adds a nice twist. This is outstanding. No traces of alcohol. Even better as it warms. Delicious.

On tap: Another disappointing beer from this brewery. Little or no aroma. The flavor was so mild to almost be nonexistent. The only thing was a slight muddy caramel and a buried wood and toast. This was watery from start to finish. I was really sorry I ordered a whole pint of this stuff.  It had the absence  of quality I would expect from a macro.
On tap at the Horseshoe pub: Nice bitterness. Lacks malt balance. Thin bodied and a little watery. Crisp mouth feel and good pilsener dryness. OK but a little disappointing.

Bottle:A dark red or brown pour. Aroma of malt and a cedar kind of woodiness. The flavor is very low key and surprisingly minor. A wood and sweet cinnamon mix. The palate is average. It is shockingly light for a beer over 10% abv. There isnt much going on here. Drinkable but boring.

12 oz bottle: Pale yellow pour with small white head. Good aroma of yeast and slight banana mixed with spices. Mellow sweet flavor of more banana and a little earthy breadiness. Thin bodied (especially compared to a Belgian tripel) with a slight alcohol tingle but nothing too distracting. A little watery on the finish. Sort of a poor mans tripel. Very drinkable. Decent.

750 ml bottle: Outstanding rocky white head that lingers. Nice aroma of yeast citrus and a mild spice. Good creamy body and smooth textured mouth feel with a little less crispness than I expected. Better as it warms with a more rounded flavor of lemon and coriander. Nice and dry. No alcohol. Bitter on the end. Delicious.

750ml bottle: Great grainy coffee foam head. Good aroma of coffee and resin and burnt chocolate. The flavor is bursting with everything you could ask from a stout. Dark chocolate and smooth coffee with nice roast notes with a full mellow body. The only negative was the nagging alcohol taste that distracted from the underlying  pleasure the flavors brought. This was near perfect but not quite.

12oz bottle: Faint murky aroma of caramel and sweet toffee. More caramel and a little cinnamon and oatmeal in the flavor. Very sweet. A very watery and thin body. This barely has the body of a porter never mind a stout. I really want to like this but I just cant get there. This is mildly flavorful and goes down well but otherwise disappointing.

22oz bottle: Hoppy nose rounded off by some dark chocolate and rich cocoa. A first class body with a silky richness and smooth tingle on the tongue. The flavor is sparked by hops but subdued by the mellow warm choco-coffee malt. Excellent! This stout is full in every respect. I want more of this.
beer_name: Smuttynose Big Beer Series: Imperial Stout

review_blob: 22oz bottle: Great hoppy nose. Very resinous and quite floral. The malt sweetness is picked up in the first sip. It meshes well with the grainy hop punch. Good crisp and creamy palate. Mild bitterness on the end. Good IPA.
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2006
beer_name: Avery The Maharaja Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: 12oz bottle: A golden orange pour with little head. An excellent aroma of orange, grapefruit and a slight hop residue. The aroma indicates a very malt based IPA. The flavor is citrus and a sharp hop undertone. Decent middle of the road body with a crisp mouthfeel. You wont find the big hop punch in this IPA. But if taken on its own terms and without hop prejudice, this is a well crafted brew.

12oz bottle (aged about a year): Light brown pour. Sweet mellow aroma with a charge of alcohol. Flavor is malty sweet and slightly bitter. The alcohol is much stronger in the aroma than the flavor. This is actually a lot more drinkable than I expected. Quite balanced actually. Excellent night cap.

12oz bottle: Huge hoppy aroma that makes me think of an IPA. Black pour. Huge hoppy flavor with a barely hanging on roasted malt. This is a very dangerous brew. Incredibly drinkable and gives no indication of the 9.1% alcohol. Good news for my mouth but bad news for my liver. A full rich body that is matched with a crisp hop bitterness. This is a very hoppy beer especially for the style. The hops could probably stand to be just slightly subdued to let a bit more of the malt texture come out. But other than that this is great. Seems like a bargain at 11$ a six pack.

12oz bottle: Aroma is malty with a floral hop whiff. A great smooth choco-coffee flavor with a fruit hop bitterness. A medium body and velvet mouthfeel coupled with creaminess make this highly drinkable. A small smoky element comes out toward the end. Excellent.
